title: Quiz 1: Fundamentals of Environmental Health
description: Test your knowledge on the core concepts, principles, and components of environmental health.

questions.question: Which statement best defines 'Environmental Health' according to WHO (1993a)?

options.text: Treating sick people in the community using traditional methods.
The theory and practice of assessing, correcting, controlling, and preventing environmental factors that can adversely affect health.
A set of personal hygiene practices aimed at preserving individual health.
Building advanced hospitals in rural areas to combat disease.

questions.explanation: WHO defines Environmental Health as the theory and practice of assessing, correcting, controlling, and preventing those factors in the environment that can potentially affect adversely the health of present and future generations. It focuses on prevention through environmental control rather than clinical treatment.
questions.hint: Think about prevention and control of external factors rather than treatment.

questions.question: Match the following environmental health components with their primary concerns:

pairs.right: Control of mammals and arthropods that transmit disease
Physiological needs and protection against accidents
Wholesomeness in production, storage, and preparation
Hygiene and safety in the workplace

questions.explanation: Vector control targets disease transmitters. Healthful housing ensures safe living conditions. Food hygiene covers safety from production to consumption. Occupational hygiene focuses on workplace safety.
questions.hint: Match the specific setting (workplace, home, food) or agent (vectors) to its description.

questions.question: Which of the following are considered 'Environmental Risk Factors'? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Environmental risk factors are external conditions like contaminated water, pollution, vectors, and sanitation facilities. Genetic disorders are internal/biological factors, not environmental.
questions.hint: Identify factors that are external to the human body and part of the environment.

questions.question: The Clinical Intervention Model focuses primarily on preventing people from getting sick by providing a healthy environment.
questions.explanation: This statement is FALSE. The Clinical Intervention Model focuses on treating the sick person (diagnosis and treatment). It is the Public Health Model that focuses on prevention through a healthy environment.
questions.hint: Does 'clinical' usually refer to treatment or prevention?

questions.question: The principle of pollution prevention that states 'polluters are responsible for paying the costs of any damage' is known as the ___BLANK___ principle.
questions.explanation: The 'Polluter Pays Principle' holds those who generate pollution accountable for the costs of managing it and any damage caused.
questions.hint: It's a three-word phrase starting with 'P'.

questions.question: What is the term for the set of practices associated with the preservation of health and healthy living, focusing mainly on personal cleanliness?
questions.explanation: Hygiene refers to practices associated with health preservation, specifically personal cleanliness (body, hair, etc.), distinct from sanitation which focuses on waste management.
questions.hint: It starts with 'H' and relates to cleanliness.

questions.question: Arrange the following steps of Environmental Health Planning in the correct logical order:
questions.explanation: The logical flow is: Identify Needs -> Set Priorities -> Write Plan -> Implement -> Monitor/Evaluate. You must know what is needed before prioritizing, plan before acting, and act before evaluating.
questions.hint: Think: What -> Which First -> How -> Do -> Check.

questions.question: Analyze the table below describing sanitation types. Which type is correctly matched with its definition?

richContent.content:
Sanitation TypeDefinition
A. Basic SanitationRecycling nutrients from wastes
B. Food SanitationControl of environmental factors in disease transmission
C. Ecological SanitationManagement of human faeces at household level
D. Onsite SanitationCollection and treatment of waste where deposited

questions.explanation: Option D is correct. 'Onsite sanitation' is treating waste where it is deposited. A describes Ecological sanitation, B describes Environmental sanitation, and C describes Basic sanitation.
questions.hint: Review the definitions carefully. 'Onsite' implies 'at the place'.

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of 'Point Sources' of water pollution? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Point sources have a definite, identifiable source and place of entry (factories, sewage plants, mines). Non-point sources are diffuse and hard to trace (agricultural runoff, storm drainage).
questions.hint: Point sources come from a single, specific location/pipe.

questions.question: What is the estimated percentage of communicable diseases in Kenya that are believed to be preventable using environmental health interventions?
questions.explanation: According to the study material, more than 80% of communicable diseases in Kenya are believed to be preventable using environmental health interventions.
questions.hint: It is a very high percentage, indicating the crucial role of environmental health.
